the bad blocks seem to make geth go into syncing mode:

```
> eth.syncing
{
  currentBlock: 10499404,
  highestBlock: 10499461,
  knownStates: 276556778,
  pulledStates: 276556778,
  startingBlock: 10499399
}
```

author: Deleted User
content:
based on geth release notes, miners that had set --miner.gaslimit intentionally (which i assume is almost all for it to be so high), it is odd that the default value itself didn't double for 1559 - is this something that would be done for 1.10.5 as we get closer or maybe never/after fork? 
release notes: 
```
To ensure that the gas available for transactions is the same as before the fork, the gas limit is doubled at the fork block. If you are using the --miner.gaslimit flag to participate in voting, you need to double the value of this flag to keep voting for the same value as before.

Example: You are using --miner.gaslimit to vote for a limit of 20M, and the actual block gas limit is 20M. When London activates, the block gas limit will adjust to 40M, but you will still be voting it down towards to 20M if you keep using the same --miner.gaslimit setting. So at some point after the fork, you need to double your --miner.gaslimit value to ensure the gas limit stays at 40M gas.
```

default config (last changed in 2019): https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/eth/ethconfig/config.go#L82-L83

author: m.kalinin
content: Do we know how often new blocks are not reaching clients on the mainnet either via `NewBlock` or `NewBlockHashes` messages which requires an explicit retrieval of such a block from the network by sending block requests? The background of this question is in the Merge transition process, which currently relies on JSON-RPC method that would send such a request if a block yet hasn't been seen by a node.

author: m.kalinin
content: If say there is a `0.1%` chance of block being missed and needed to be explicitly requested it would mean that we can potentially avoid implementation of such a method and rely on a gossip

author: perama
content:
Here is an account that, within the 1000 block window used for `1559.dat` & the charts above, demonstrates spamming that explains the cluster at ~80% gas used.

It has a run of ~20 txs (to the same inactive address) each with 12 million gas, at a time when the gas limit was 15 million (12/15=80%). For many of those blocks, the gas utilisation is indeed ~80%.

https://ropsten.etherscan.io/address/0x863174ab4923c301cade3d85a333e88e255b4259

https://ropsten.etherscan.io/block/10499620
